news politics covid-rule-changes-way-whatll-"Boris Johnson denies allegations MPs were blackmailedByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Jan | comments Sajid Javid has declared Covid will be with us “perhaps forever” - and plans to axe all restrictions in England from the spring and summer.The Health Secretary confirmed Plan B rules are axed over the next week adding: “Covid is not going away. “It’s going to be with us for many many years, perhaps forever, and we have to learn to live with it.”But he was warned relaxing Plan B coronavirus curbs is “too much, too soon”, amid fears over the impact of scrapping measures. Work from home guidance has been axed in England and children were allowed to take off their masks in classrooms today as experts said the Omicron wave had peaked.Next Thursday, Covid passes are no longer needed and face coverings will no longer be mandatory in indoor public spaces in England, including on public transport.  Self-isolation laws for infected people are due to expire in March - and could be axed sooner. But there were growing fears lting measures could trigger a resurgence in the highly-transmissible iant. Latest data today showed another , infections and  deaths. Union leaders believe easing curbs could backfire - and TV doctor Hilary Jones agreed.This is a worry to many, many people. Itaposs not just me who thinks itaposs too much too soon,” he told ITV ’s Good Morning Britain. “Teachers, NHS providers, the Royal College of Nursing, Unison - theyaposre all very concerned that taking away all restrictions suddenly, despite the data, is too much too soon.So what rules are being scrapped, when - and what will stay  Here’s a full run-down.Rules that are set to be scrapped January : Working from home guidance endsSince December  people were urged to “work from homeyou can” in England. But that was axed immediately in an announcement by Boris Johnson on Wednesday  January. The guidance, which was not legally binding, was a key way of getting cases down. But officials admitted it had “immediate costs to the economy”. “People should speak to their employers about arrangements for ing to the office,” the Department of Health said. There is still “working safely guidance” about how to keep Covid cases down, including ventilation and regular cleaning. January : Masks in classrooms axedEnglandaposs secondary schools had told students and staff to wear face masks in the classroom since January . Those rules have been axed as of today, with masks in communal areas continuing to be recommended for another week.Week of January : Covid travel tests could be axed for the vaccinatedVaccinated travellers will soon be allowed toto the UK without taking a Covid test at all,a change gets the go-ahead. Currently vaccinated travellers must take a lateral flow test within two days of ing to Britain. Anyone who tests positive must isolate for ten days, although this can be cut short with a negative lateral flow test on days six and seven.But Transport SecretaryGrant Shappsis looking at removing this last UK test requirement for vaccinated travellers by the end of January.Any announcement is likely in the week of January , the Mirror understands. Unjabbed travellers would still need to take UK arrival tests - and of course, British tourists may still have to take tests when heading abroad. January : Compulsory masks scrapped in all settingsFace masks were made compulsory in England in two waves through winter, first on public transport, then in shops. They are also mandatory in shopping malls, taxis, banks, post offices, hair salons, barbers, nail salons, pharmacies, vets, auction houses, takeaways , estate agents. All those laws will be axed at .am on Thursday  January. At the same time, so will guidance on wearing masks in school corridors and halls. But wearing a mask will still be recommended in some settings, evenit’s not legally binding.Health Secretary Sajid Javid said: I think it will be sensible on the tube in London, for example - quite an enclosed space. People will be asked to make their own personal judgment just as we do in fighting flu.January : Covid passes axed for nightclubsSince December , nightclubs and large events like gigs and football matches in England had to ask punters for proof of either a vaccine, or negative lateral flow test. But the law that enforces Covid ‘passports’ expires at .pm on Wednesday  January and will not be renewed. Covid passes can still be used by nightclubs voluntarily but this appears unlikely to be widespread.Boris Johnsonwould likely have needed to put any extension to a vote - and last time around  Tory MPs rebelled.The Prime Minister is already battling for survival over Downing Street parties, and another huge revolt could have been be fatal.Date not known: Definition of fully-jabbed will include a boosterThe government has repeatedly said it will update the definition of fully-jabbed to include a booster in England. While this will no longer matter for domestic Covid passes , it will matter for whether you isolate when entering the UK. Scotland already made this change for its Covid passes on January , for anyone whose second dose was at least four months ago. England has been holding out on announcing a date, because so many people had Covid over Christmas. The infections meant they were unable to get a vaccine for  days afterwards. Date not known: Daily testing for Covid contacts could be cutThe self-isolation period for people with Covid was shortened this week to at least five full days in England.Butyou’re a contact of someone with Covid, you still need to take a daily lateral flow test forsevendays .The government has said it will review this guidance - hinting it could be cut to five days too - but has not given a date for a change.March  : Isolation for positive Covid cases scrappedBoris Johnson has announced he “very much expects” to scrap legally-binding isolation for all Covid-positive people from March . This will be a massive change, and end almost exactly two years of legally-enforced isolation for people who test positive for the virus. Health Secretary Sajid Javid has said the dates are not final but an announcement could be made “in the next few weeks”. Boris Johnson told MPs: “As Covid becomes endemic we will need to replace legal requirements with advice and guidance urging people with the virus to be careful and considerate of others. The self-isolation regulations expire on th March, at which point I very much expect not to renew them. Indeed were the data to allow, I would like to seek a vote in this House to bring that date forwards.Spring : Shutting down PCR testing centresLocal Covid testing centres will start to be shut down from the spring, according to The Times. Since the multi-billion pound Test and Trace programme was set up, a huge network of testing centres has ballooned in places like car parks. The average person in England travels just . miles to get a test. Ministers reportedly accept this cannot be sustained long-term, with a source telling The Times: “The wind-down will be quite swt and will mean fewer test centres because we donapost need all of the sites.”End of June : Free lateral flow tests scrappedThe government made clear in autumn  that at some point, free mass lateral flow tests would end and people would start having to pay. Now a leaked document has suggested officials have pencilled in a date of the end of June, after it was put back from Spring amid an outcry. The government has declined to say what the tests cost, with one source suggesting it is £ for a seven-pack. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said: Lateral flow tests remain free to use and we continue to encourage people to access them. “At a later stage the Government, as our response to the virus evolves, universal free provision of things like lateral flow tests will end and we will update once we are in that position. Thereaposs been no decision made on when that will be.”Rules that are set to stay Guidance on masks and testingDespite most laws being axed in England, there is likely to still be guidance on keeping yourself and vulnerable relatives safe. This can include keeping rooms well-ventilated, meeting outdoors where possible and taking a lateral flow test before you go. The government added: “Public health guidance will remain in place, suggesting iniduals should continue to wear a face covering in crowded and enclosed spaces, where you may come into contact with people you do not normally meet.”Compulsory vaccines for NHS and care staff Covid vaccines will be made mandatory for all frontlineNHSstaff in England from April  as a “condition of deployment”.It is already a condition of deployment in care homes despite fears of mass staff shortages, which have prompted a relaxation of immigration rules. The Department of Health and Social Care accepted there may be a “signicant” hit to the workforce as millions are told ‘no jab, no job’. A government impact statement has now estimated , health and care staff could refuse to be vaccinated under the policy, without having a medical exemption. But Mr Javid said NHS staff already need vaccines against other illnesses and it will protect patients.Regular booster vaccinesScientists have repeatedly said there will be an annual booster programme for Covid, either for the whole population or just the vulnerable. Sajid Javid said: “The one thing we’ve learned about flu, because it’s been around for far longer, is we have annual vaccinations, for older people in particular, for children as well. “We may well have some kind of annual vaccination. I think that’s where we’ll probably end up, but it’s really dficult for anyone to say exactly in the longer term where we’ll be.”Keeping powers in reserveJust because legal powers are axed, it does not mean they won’t be brought back. The government has the power to lay Covid restrictions at any time under public health laws dating back to . news politics labour-working-woo-more-defectors-"PMQs: Keir Starmer welcomes Christian WakefordByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Labour is working to lure more Tory MPs away from Boris Johnson as the Prime Minister faces an anxious wait for the kne-edge Partygate report. Several potential defectors are being wooed by the party in the aftermath of Christian Wakeford’s bombshell switch, it is understood.Sources warned against any imminent defection - but one suggested there could be a breakthrough in future. The source said the door is always open, adding: “I’m not expecting an imminent second one - but that doesn’t mean there won’t be one. “We’ll have to see what happens over the next few weeks.”  The PM’s position temporarily stabilised following Mr Wakeford’s dramatic decision, with claims some no-confidence letters had been withdrawn. Backbench MP Andrew Percy said Mr Wakeford’s defection had “kind of made people a bit more relaxed, itaposs calmed nerves”. He added: “I think people have recognised that actually this constant navel gazing and internal debating is only to the advantage of our political opponents. “The Prime Minister is probably thanking Christian for what he did because itaposs made a lot of people think again, think twice.But Mr Wakeford was in talks with Labour for months, pre-dating Partygate after he privately voiced concerns about the direction of the government.And today’s Tory unity may just be a stay of execution as No braces for next week’s make-or-break investigation by senior civil servant Sue Gray.Senior Tory William Wragg, who has already called for Mr Johnson to quit, today accused government figures of aposblackmailapos to persuade MPs to stay loyal.  Veteran Tories could seal Mr Johnson’s fate next week after the report is published. Insiders fear it will not fully clear the PM. Itaposs not going to be as good as people think,” a Government source told the Times. “Sheaposs genuinely struggling to reconcile the Prime Ministeraposs claim that this was a work event with what sheaposs been hearing from other people. “Itaposs very dficult for her. One Labour source said: “There are obviously a number of people on the Tory benches who are feeling uncomfortable with their current position, and reflecting on whether they’re in the right.“It’s a massive show of confidence in the Labour Party that someone who’s been in the Conservative Party can see this is a party serious about government.”But they warned against any imminent new defections and said: “Other people have expressed dissatisfaction with where they are but that doesn’t necessarily mean they’ll cross the floor - it takes a tremendous amount of courage to do that.”  A second source said: “I don’t think there’s any imminently because it’s such a big political thing. “The first one is the hardest - no one doing it for  years creates a kind of aura about it that’s quite hard to break. But it’s a big thing to do regardless... I’m not aware of anyone whose headspace is ‘I’m in the wrong party’.”Health Secretary Sajid Javid desperately tried to shore up the PM, saying he thought Mr Johnson was secure in his post - despite calls from some Tory MPs for him to resign over Downing Street lockdown parties.Askedthe PM was safe in his job, Mr Javid said: Yes, I think he is. At the same time, people are right to be angered and pained about what they have seen and they have heard. I share that anger and pain. “I think it is right that there is a proper investigation going on that will establish the facts and that the Prime Minister will come back to Parliament and properly respond. Mr Javid called for Mr Wakeford to trigger a by-election in his Bury South seat.  Mr Javid admitted David Davisaposs call for the PM to quit was damaging for Mr Johnson.The former Brexit Secretary quoted from the  Norway Debate when he urged Mr Johnson to stand aside, telling him In the name of God, go.Mr Javid conceded: It is damaging, of course it is. The Health Secretary also said thatMr Johnson was found to have broken the law he would have to go. The Ministerial Code is very clear. If any minister from the Prime Minister down breaks the law, of course they shouldnapost continue to serve as a minister, he said. What I have just said is a general rule that applies to everyone. There is no exception to that rule. He admitted the scandal had damaged UK democracy. If there were people at the heart of government who were not following the rules, absolutely they should be disciplined and I look forward to seeing that disciplinary action taking place, he said. We do now know there were some parties. We know that because some of the people that were involved and broke the rules have come forward to say so. Of course things like this damage our democracy.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyLabour PartyDavid DavisBoris JohnsonCivil servantsPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i uncovered family secret after
story: I uncovered family secret after taking home DNA test to find my biological dadKristin Shoonveld, , donated her eggs in , hoping to help a couple have a child. She thought little more of it until a home DNA kit she took in  revealed something incredibleKristin and Parker met just before the pandemicByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsA woman discovered a son she never knew she had after receiving results from a home DNA kit. Kristin Shoonveld, who is adopted, bought a test in autumn of  in the hope she might find out more about her biological father. Twenty-five years earlier, Kristin, now  donated her eggs in the hope sheaposd be able to give someone  a baby - but she hadnapost thought much about it. But after receiving her results from a andMe DNA test, the special needs worker from Indiana in the US saw that she had a son listed on the database. She told PEOPLE magazine she thought it was a mistake at first, having never carried a child of her own. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. But after clicking on his profile, she was shocked to see the young man looked like her. And he had joined the  looking for his biological mother. Although she never had kids of her own, Kristin met Nick, a then nine-year-old boy with Down syndrome, while she was working in an SEN school. She instantly took Nick under her wing and looked out for him. Before long, she met Nickaposs mum, Grace, and the pair got on well. Sadly, Grace was diagnosed with lung cancer and became very unwell. While she was sick, Kristin took on more responsibility for Nick until Grace tragically passed away.  After she died in January , Kristin was there for Nick as sheaposd always been, but she became concerned about his dad, Brian. Kristin said: I was just one of many people who were really worried about how Brian and Nick were going to manoeuver through le, she says. I was mostly worried about them just being just overwhelmed with grief. As Kristin spent more time with Brian, the pair fell in love and married in . That same year, she officially adopted Nick. The adoption was what spurred her on to find out more about her own biological family - and before long, sheaposd found her biological mother. But, still without answers about her father, she took a DNA test in the hope she might find him. After making the incredible discovery about her son, Parker Erickson, Kristin reached out to him and the pair arranged to meet. It was just instant love, she said. Parker, from Santa Cruz in Calornia, found out he was conceived via egg donor when he was . After meeting his biological mother for the first time, he said it was instantly easy to love each other. And Kristinaposs son Nick was similarly thrilled to meet Parker, telling Kristin he always wanted a brother. Kristin said: Weaposve established a relationship thataposs going to last the rest of our lives. title: boy left teeth nose after
story: Boy left with teeth in his nose after gruesome accident on hotel water slideWARNING: DISTRESSING IMAGES Stunned mum Kelly Grfiths from Bridgend, Wales, said her son Louis ended up with teeth in his nose after a frightful accident at a water park while on holiday in TurkeyLouis was left seriously injured in the shocking accident while on holiday Image: Kelly GrfithsByAlice Suffield:,  Jan | commentsA -year-old boy was left with horrying injuries in a devastating accident on a hotel water slide. Stunned mum Kelly Grfiths said her son Louis ended up with teeth in his nose after the water at the pool was turned off. Grim photos show the treatment the schoolboy had to go through to get his smile back. Kelly told Wales Online there was blood everywhere and Louis had to be rushed to hospital. She said: I was actually back in the room, it was about .pm and Iaposd headed back up so I could shower before tea and thataposs when the kids my son had been at the pool with had come up to the room and said aposLouisapos knocked his front teeth outapos. Louis and some other kids had been climbing up the waterslide after the water had been turned off.His friend had made it up and had reached out his hand to pull Louis but he couldnapost grab it and fell flat on his face. His cousin Mason had carried him to the showers and there was blood everywhere.When I got down there they were already rushing him through into the doctoraposs room at the hotel and  mins later we were on our way to hospital.Louis, from Bridgend, was on a week-long family holiday in Antalya, Turkey, with his mum, nan, and his cousin, when he suffered the serious injuries. Kelly continues the story: We eventually were sent to the emergency dentist where he was seen by an oral surgeon. His teeth had been pushed all the way up into his nasal cavity, so it looked like he had a broken nose. Thanks to her former job, Kelly was well aware of what was at risk.  She said: Having been a dental nurse, I knew exactly how bad this could be, and it only made me worry more. These were his adult teeth so I knew he was at risk of losing them. Louis was operated on there at the dental surgery and had his teeth repositioned and splinted, all whilst he was awake. Kelly said: They gave him five injections of local anaesthetic and they cut his gum open and pulled the teeth back down and had them positioned by the splint. I think he was just in shock, in this country he would have been put to sleep. The holiday was ruined after that, and we were only on day two. We just wanted to come home.Louis couldnapost do anything, he couldnapost eat or drink properly and he couldnapost go in the pool. When the family ed to Wales, Louisaposs dentist had him referred to see specialists at Morriston Hospital, where the journey began to get his smile back. After ious treatment options had been exhausted, he was referred to Dr Rohini Mohan, Swansea Bay’s clinical lead for Community Dental Services, who successfully treated Louis at the Neath Port Talbot Resource Centre following the August  incident – and gave him back a perfect smile. Dr Mohan said: “The pictures of Louis have been inspirational to show other children who have suffered a trauma that you can come through it.It helps their parents as well. The worst can happen, and you can still come out with a beautul smile. Kelly said she couldnapost thank the dental team enough for helping Louis get his smile back. She said: Dr Rohini and her team were absolutely amazing. I canapost thank them enough for everything theyaposve done for Louis. title: christian couple ban gay men
story: Christian couple ban gay men from buying home - and refuse to let them insideLuke Whitehouse and Lachlan Mantell wanted to buy a house but the sellers told them they would not be allowed to even view it as they believe homosexuality is contrary to Gods wordLuke Whitehouse and Lachlan Mantell fell in love with the £,, three-bed Image: Triangle NewsByAndy CrickTom ParrySpecial correspondentDanya Bazaraa:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A gay couple who inquired about a house they wanted to buy were banned by the owners from even viewing it as they said homosexuality is “contrary to the word of God”.Luke Whitehouse and Lachlan Mantell were sent a message from the sellers, who are Christians, citing Bible passages that are used to condemn same-sex relationships.Luke and Lachlan, who have been together for eight years, planned to view the house in Coulsdon, Surrey last Saturday.But on the Wednesday before they got a message back from the sellers via Purplebricks, MailOnline reports.It read: Dear Lachlan and Luke, thank you for sharing your circumstances with us.Weaposre sorrywe seem intrusive, but we just want to make clear that we would be unwilling for two men in a partnership to view or buy our house. Have you had a similar experience  Email webnews@mirrorAs it is contrary to the gracious teaching in Godaposs Word, the Holy Bible, e.g Romans :- and Jude  . With regards.Speaking about his reaction, Luke said: “For the first  seconds I laughed – I thought it was a joke. But then I was upset and I had a cry on the phone to my mum. Homophobia still exists.”Business owner Luke, , and ITV producer Lachlan, , said it was their first attempt to view a house as they look to get on the property ladder. Luke and Lachlan - originally from Adelaide, Australia - are desperate to get their own place after being kept apart during the pandemic, He said: We were separated during Covid, he was in America while I was here, we were forced apart. Buying a house was something that we wanted to do for a long time. But this was the only house we planned for a viewing. We were looking forward to going this weekend.  He added: Since I came out eight years ago I have not come across discirimation. I probably have been discriminated against but was just not aware of it. Luke, of Putney, south west London said they wouldnapost buy or even view the house eventhe owners apologised and changed their mind. He added: We will look for something  now We are not going to let it affect us trying to buy a house.  Married couple Luke Main, , a builder, and medical physicist Dr Joanna Brunker, , own the £,, three-bed home in Coulsdon, South London. Dr Brunker reportedly hit back at the criticism by saying: “We’re practising Christians and are sticking to our beliefs and haven’t done anything wrong.”Luke reported it to the online estate agents who were selling it via Rightmove.They are set to stop selling the property saying the comments from the owners are against its views and values.A Purplebricks spokesperson told them: Thanks for sharing this message Lachlan and weaposre so sorry youaposve had this experience.This stance is completely opposed to our views and values.Weaposll refund this selleraposs fee as Purplebricks no longer wish to list it. A Purplebricks spokesperson added: The sentiments expressed in this message are completely opposed to Purplebricksapos views and values.We have contacted the seller totheir fee and request that they sell their property with a dferent agent.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CrimeGayDaily MirrorHousing,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dad named one sickest covid
story: Dad named one of sickest Covid patients comes off oxygen a year after getting virusAndrew Watts, , of Bexley, south London, spent a total of  hours in hospital and had to relearn how to walk and talk following eight months in intensive careAndrew Watts, , was finally able tohome after  days in hospital Image: BPM MEDIAByLucy WilliamsonLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA dad described one of the sickest ever Covid patients has just started breathing without oxygen support more than a year after catching the virus. Andrew Watts, , had one of the longest hospital stays doctors had ever seen after spending eight months in intensive care followed by another two months on a ward.The dad-of-two spent  days at Queen Elizabeth Hospital where he was admitted with Covid- pneumonia on Christmas Day in .In February, after a five-week induced coma and two le-threatening lung collapses, doctors called Mr Wattsapos we Hayley to discuss switching off his ventilator because his condition had deteriorated so badly.But the family insisted he should be given more time and he has since left hospital - and now he has come off a nasal cannula for the first time, reports My London.Mr Watts, from Bexley in South London, was finally able to go home in October and said he is doing well but still battles with ongoing complications.  The cab driver, who was in remission from lymph cancer at the time, had to relearn how to walk and talk after spending so long on a ventilator. In intensive care, he used a tracheostomy pipe and had to communicate with his we using letters on a board. Only a week and a half ago, I came off a nasal cannula for the first time since leaving hospital, Mr Watts said. I used it for nine hours every night to aid my recovery to help my lungs get back to some sort of normality. The cabbie told how he has not healed properly after the ventilator and tube was in his neck for so long in hospital. Thataposs why there is a whistle when Iaposm talking as there is essentially a hole in my neck where air comes out, he added.  I canapost get water in it or it makes me cough like mad. I could get an infection which means I canapost go swimming and I canapost shower the way I want to. Mr Wattsapos family, including Hayley and sons Jack, six, and Joshua, three, have all supported his recovery. In November, Mr Watts said his major goal was to walk his sons to school and he can currently walk for up to  minutes walking before his legs start burning. I managed to get to my son’s school and back last Monday. I say that - we parked around the corner, so it wasnapost the full way. But still, he said. I think people should be grateful that they can do these little tasks. Day-to-day, when youaposre fit and healthy, you just do these things and donapost think about.  But when it got taken away from me, it made me realise not to take it for granted. When Mr Watts first went into hospital in December , he had not been vaccinated, due to the very early stage of the vaccination campaign - but he has since had three doses of a Covid vaccine. Looking back on his experience, which included doctors at one time calling his family to tell them they were considering turning his ventilator off, Mr Watts urged others to get vaccinated. When in hospital, he recalled how they did not believe that vaccinations would do anything and that the whole pandemic was a conspiracy. “The fact that there are people that know what Iaposve been through and still say that, he said. Itaposs up to iniduals. If it was me, I would tell them to go and get it. If they decide not to get it, then that’s their own fault. Andrew said he was badly impacted by the virus because he was in remission from lymph cancer after successful chemotherapy treatment. It comes as the Prime Minister today announced the end of Plan B measures - with the onus now falling on the British public to mitigate the risks of Covid. Mr Watts welcomes the change, despite still being clinically vulnerable. He said I want everyone to live their lives to the max, this isnapost going anywhere we’ve got to learn to live with it. “I could wrap myself in cotton wool and live in a box but then whataposs the point in living  I want the world to get back” “Itaposs unlikely I would get it again. Iaposm taking necessary precautions, I have kids that go to school, but what can you do  I wear a mask where I have to and continue to wash my hands because otherwise whataposs the point  Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Oxygen OneCoronavirus vaccineCoronavirusHospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: family welcomes first girl born
story: Family welcomes first girl born in  years with touching photo of  generationsGreat-grandmother Gwen Smith, , from Northfleet, Kent, welcomed baby Maeva - the first girl born into her family since her own daughter in Gwen Smith meets her great great granddaughter MaevaByAdam Gillham:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A -year-old pensioner has greeted her great-great-granddaughter into the world - the first girl born into the family for  years.Gwen Smith met little Maeva for the first time - the first female born to the Smiths since her daughter Sandra in .Five generations of the family were able to get together at the Dene Holm Residential Care Home in Northfleet, Kent, as the oldest and youngest members could be united for the first time.Gwen, who will turn  next month, already has five grandsons, eight great-grandsons and six step-great-grandsons - and she was extremely proud to meet the newest addition to the family. Unfortunately, her cataracts mean she can no longer see very well, but she was still tremendously happy to meet Maeva. Gwen’s family said: “It was a very special occasion to get all five generations together, particularly during the pandemic. Strict protocols are still in place but the home’s manager, Chris, permitted the visit for which we are all extremely grateful.” Gwen was born in Essex on February , , and moved to Gravesend as a youngster, attending school in Northfleet. She was a keen dancer in her youth and performed at many local events while working for her father’s shop.  Gwen met her husband, Ron, an apprentice electrician at Blue Circle Cement Works, when she was . They married in , but with Ron sent to serve overseas in the Royal Engineers they didn’t meet again for another five years. When they were finally reunited the pair enjoyed many years of travelling whilst bringing up their two daughters, Gloria and Sandra. A care home spokesman said: It can be dficult to get several generations of family together at the best of times but with an ongoing pandemic, it’s even trickier. But thanks to the staff at the Dene Holm Road care home, Gwen’s family were able to come and visit her together, to introduce her to baby Maeva. It was a very rare occasion and indeed, incredibly special for the whole family, particularly as little Maeva is the first girl to be born to the family since Gwen’s daughter, Sandra,  years ago. story: Happy, cheeky, funny boy, , dies after being hit by train at railway stationDevin Gordon, , was reportedly hit by a train near Bathgate railway station in West Lothian, Scotland, on Wednesday, according to British Transport PoliceDevin Gordon was reportedly hit by a train Image: Bathgate Juniors Football ClubByDan BarkerRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments The family of a teenager who died after reportedly being hit by a train have said their lives will never be the same without our precious boy. Devin Gordon, , died near Bathgate railway station in West Lothian, Scotland, on Wednesday afternoon, British Transport Policesaid.In a tribute to the keen footballer, his family said he will live in our hearts forever. In their statement, issued by the police, they continued: Our lives have changed forever and will never be the same without our precious boy. We will miss him every day for the rest of our lives. Thank-you to everyone thataposs paid tribute to Devin and those that have sent us condolence messages during this extremely dficult time.Have you been affected by this incident  Let us know at webnews@mirrorHearts fan Devin was a member of Bathgate Juniors Football Club, which described him as a great team player and friend who will be greatly missed by his football family. It said: Devin was a light in the team which will never go out. His personality like a magnet drawing people to him. Happy, cheeky but funny with it and always respectful. On the field he showed his passion and skill. He made the team a better place to be. He was a great team player and friend who will be greatly missed by his football family. Our thoughts are now with Devinaposs family, friends and his team who will hold him in their hearts foreverthe only number .  Emergency services had attended the scene, but could not save the youngster. Police said his death is not been treated as suspicious and a report will be sent to the procurator fiscal. Emergency services raced to the scene at around .pm yesterday but sadly the teen could not be saved and was pronounced dead. A BTP statement said: British Transport Police were called to Bathgate station at .pm todayfollowing reports of a casualty on the tracks. Paramedics also attended, and sadly a person was pronounced dead at the scene. The incident is not being treated as suspicious and a file will be prepared for the procurator fiscal. Devinaposs friends are hoping to get a -minute applause around Heartsapos Tynecastle Park when the side face Celtic next Wednesday. title: man slept ae chair 4
story: Man slept on AE chair for  nights after arriving with spreading skin complaintJohn Evans, , arrived at Cardfs University Hospital, Wales, with a skin infection which was rapidly spreading across his face - but was left shocked at the conditions staff were working inDespite the inadequate conditions, John praised the staff for trying their best and being so caring Image: InternetByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A man spent four nights sleeping on an AE chair after arriving with a fast-spreading skin condition.John Evans arrived at Cardfaposs University Hospital in Wales with a skin infection spreading across his face. The -year-old said he had experienced the skin problem before, so knew he needed urgent treatment and antibiotics.But as he waited for a hospital bed to become free, John said he was left on a chair for four nights - despite staff doing their best in tough working conditions.Speaking about his hospital ordeal, John said: I was really shocked by the conditions that the patients and staff were in. There was only one toilet to use and no hot food. Despite the inadequate conditions, John praised the staff for trying their best and being so caring, reports the BBC.He said: The staff did a fantastic job and they worked really hard and theyaposre so caring, but they were under real pressure as well. There was a sense of helplessness from the staff to the point where they had to just manage their way through a horric situation, caring for people in this way. Iaposd always believed that the health service was thereI needed it. Cardf and Vale health board said it was in touch with Mr Evans and sincerely apologised.  In a statement, the board said: Our services are under extreme pressure due to a number of factors including current staff shortages and the sustained challenges coronavirus presents.In addition, health and social care services across Cardf and the Vale of Glamorgan are experiencing signicant and sustained pressures which is impacting the timely discharge of patients from hospital. These and other challenges are impacting on patient flow within our sites and, in turn, waiting times in our emergency unit. In this instance, we sincerely apologise for the delays and experience for Mr Evans, and our concerns team are in touch with him to respond directly to the concerns raised.There are currently , beds in Welsh hospitals occupied by medically fit people who cannot secure care and thus cannot be released from AE.As a result, more than , patients waited more than  hours to be admitted to AE in Wales during November. news uk-news meghan-markle-prince-harry-might-"Prince Harry files claim over police protection for familyByLorraine KingNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Prince Harry and Meghan Markle could miss Prince Philip’s upcoming memorialtheir security fight is not resolved.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are expected to attend the service in spring this year and finally introduce seven-month old Lilibet to the Queen and other members of the royal family.But the plans are on hold due to Harryaposs legal dispute with the UK Government over a decision not to let him pay for police protection for his family when he is visiting.A legal representative of the prince said he wants to bring Lilibet and two-year-old son Archie to visit from the US but they are “unable toto his home” because it is too dangerous. Last July, Harry was reportedly chased by a pack of photographers after he attended a charity event with sick children at Kew Gardens, west London.Whose side are you on  Have your say in the comment section The -year-old had flown back briefly from LA for the July  unveiling of the Diana, Princess of Wales memorial statue. The Sussexes have their own security in the US, but sources said the privately paid-for team have no authority whatsoever in the UK.And one royal source has now told Page Six : “If Harry goes, he will want to have security for him and his family. If and when he decides to go back to the UK, he needs security.” The couple have not announced any official travel plans for  as yet but it has been widely believed they would attend the service in memory of the Duke of Edinburgh who died last April at the age of . This would be the first time Lilbet would meet her paternal side of her family as Meghan has not ed to the UK since the couple officially quit royal le in March  and lost their taxpayer-funded police protection. The Mirror has contacted the Sussexes for a comment.  On Saturday, Harryaposs legal representatives said that he has filed a claim for judicial review because he wants to fund the security himself, rather than ask taxpayers to foot the bill. He has argued that his private protection team in the US does not have the necessary jurisdiction abroad, or access to UK intelligence that is needed to keep his family safe.In a statement to PA news agency, the legal representative for the Duke said: “The UK will always be Prince Harry ’s home and a country he wants his we and children to be safe in. “With the lack of police protection, comes too great a personal risk. “The Duke and Duchess of Sussex personally fund a private security team for their family, yet that security cannot replicate the necessary police protection needed whilst in the UK. “In the absence of such protection, Prince Harry and his family are unable toto his home.” The legal representative added: “Prince Harry inherited a security risk at birth, for le. He remains sixth in line to the throne, served two tours of combat duty in Afghanistan, and in recent years his family has been subjected to well-documented neo-Nazi and extremist threats.  “While his role within the Institution has changed, his profile as a member of the Royal Family has not. Nor has the threat to him and his family.” The bid for a judicial review was filed in September. Dai Davies, former head of Scotland Yard’s royal protection unit, told the Mirror: If ever there was a proper credible threat to Prince Harry or his family then the Met would take the appropriate action. “If he or his family were toto Britain in an official capacity or to support the Queen during the Platinum Jubilee events I’m sure he would be afforded the necessary protection. “I would argue robustly against his case that he is not safe in the UK. If ever the British intelligence services did discover a threat to him and his family they are hardly going to sit on it. It appears that Harry is creating scenarios that do not exist.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Meghan MarklePrince HarryPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum 63 sheds 5st chucks
story: Mum, , sheds st and chucks old swimsuit away after family creates own fat loss dietEmma Scrivener, , from Swansea, Wales, and her family shed an impressive st in just months after inventing their own clean living dietEmma Scrivener, husband Tony, their daughter Katie Thomas and husband Shaun invented the diet Image: DA GroupByAndrea Blazquez:,  Jan | comments A family lost a combined  stone between them after coming up with their own diet.Emma Scrivener, , her husband Tony, their daughter mum-of-three Katie Thomas and husband Shaun created a plan that they say is easy to stick to. Emma, from Swansea, Wales, explained she was a size  when she decided to lose weight following a health scare.My blood pressure was extremely high and I had problems with my back and realised that something had to be done before I got progressively worse, she told the . Also we had been on a holiday and after seeing myself in a swimsuit realised I had piled on the weight.Have you been through a weight loss journey like Emma and her family  Let us know at webnews@mirror I had to make the decision that I would do nothing and regret it later or make the changes before it became too late. She went on to say she never expected to drop down to a size , but knewshe could get to a size  she would be very happy. What has become known as the DA diet consists of most foods, including treats like chocolate, crisps and cake.  But is about portion control. Emma said many people may be eating well but eating far too much. Her plan is well balanced with the correct amounts of protein, fats and carbohydrates.  It took her around  months to reach her target weight, losing five stone, as she was going through menopause. Shaun, on the other hand, lost five stone in five months, while Katie lost two stone in three months and Tony three and a half in five months. Emma said it should never be a race to lose weight and it is about each inidualaposs well-being. She admits her le has drastically changed after sticking it out, with no blood pressure issues or aches and pains. Emma was able to throw her old swimsuits away and now has no body confidence issues.The family started their weight loss journey in  and have since set up the DA Group which provides plans, as well as natural supplements, and includes Facebook groups and mentoring.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON DA GroupBlood pressureDietMenopauseSwimming costumesWeight loss success stories" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum who sent 6000 run
story: Mum who sent £, to on-the-run drug dealer boyfriend in Dubai spared jailAnnie Webster, , from Liverpool, wired £,. to her then-boyfriend and renowned drug dealer Shawn OMalley, who was on the run from police in Dubai in relation to a gangland shootingAnnie Webster, , of Cumberland Street, Warrington, appeared back in Liverpool Crown Court on Thursday Image: Liverpool EchoByCharlotte Hadfield:,  Jan | commentsA mum who sent more than £, to her drug dealing boyfriend who was on the run over a shooting in Dubai was today spared jail. Annie Webster, , wired £,. to her then-partner Shawn OaposMalley, who was on the run from police following the shooting in Bolton. OaposMalley, from Warrington, was wanted by police in relation to a shooting in Bolton on September , , when a house was sprayed with bullets. He was jailed for  years at Liverpool Crown Court in September, after being convicted for the attack which he organised on behalf of Warrington criminal Leon Cullen.His prison sentence also related to the torture of two men at a remote cannabis farm, where he tied, beat and threatenedthem with weapons including a pickaxe and sledgehammer, the Liverpool Echo reports. In July, Bolton Crown Court heard how OaposMalleyaposs partner Webster sent thousands of pounds to him while he was on the run in Dubai in relation to a gangland shooting. When police visited Websteraposs home in January  she told them she had split from OaposMalley in November  and was no longer in contact with him. On March , , police executed a warrant at Websteraposs home in Warrington, when she was arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice. During a search of her house police recovered a number of items including a Western Union Money Transfer Document in her name, an Emirates Economy Boarding Pass in her name and a receipt voucher for a Dubai-based law firm. From a storage area under the stairs in her home, police found a money transfer receipt for £. dated February , , a Ghaya Brand Hotel luggage claim ticket, a money transfer receipt dated February , , and her passport. Following a police search and interview, Webster pleaded guilty to concealing, disguising, converting, transferring or removing criminal property. A charge of conspiring to pervert the course of justice will also lay on file. Webster, of Cumberland Street, Warrington, was sentenced to a two-year community order with a -day rehabilitation activity requirement at Bolton Crown Court back in July last year.  But she appeared back in Liverpool Crown Court today where she admitted breaching the terms of her community order. Rebecca Smith, prosecuting, told the court Webster has so far completed five days of the rehabilitation activity requirement since the community order was imposed last summer. However, the -year-old failed to attend two planned appointments with probation in September and November . Websteraposs defence barrister, Kate Morley, told the court her client suffers with anxiety and depression and finds it easier to engage on the telephone as opposed to leaving her home to attend office appointments at times. Ms Morley said Webster had missed the appointments in September and November due to childcare issues with her six-year-old son, who was unwell and has had to have six teeth removed.The court heard Webster also had to self-isolate after her mum tested positive for Covid- until she received a negative test result.Ms Morley said while her client should have picked up the phone and informed probation of this she didnapost and she apologises for that.  The court heard Webster is now working in a local bar and hasnapost committed any other offences. Ms Morley said: She has attended today despite her father sadly suffering a heart attack and passing away last week. Sentencing, Judge Robert Trevor-Jones said: Iaposm quite sure that when you were sentenced to this community order back in June last year you would have been told what would happenyou failed to comply with it, so here you are now because of that. The judge said that while he had the power to revoke Websteraposs community order and resentence her to imprisonment, he was not going to do that on the grounds that this is her first conviction and first breach, and because she has a six-year-old son. However, he warned thatWebster continues not to meet the requirements of the community order she will be brought back to court to face the consequences. Webster was handed a fine of £ which must be paid over the next six months. title: nursery accidentally sends parents secret
story: Nursery accidentally sends parents secret letter of string of worrying mistakesOne incident claimed that a child became trapped in the toilet crying and shaking while another almost escaped from the nursery in Enderby, LeicestershireStaff at Welcome Nurseries, which owns Smarties, in Enderby, mistakenly posted the message Image: Andy Baker Leicestershire LiveByCorey BedfordLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Nursery staff accidentally posted a secret letter to parents revealing a string of mistakes including a boy getting stuck in the loo and a near escape.Staff at Welcome Nurseries, which owns Smarties, posted a message by mistake on the Family nursery app which is used to communicate with mums and dads. Another incident claimed a toddler was left to sit with dried faeces on his leg and another child was trapped in the toilet crying and shaking, according to the file. The horrying message said they wouldnapost be surprisedOfsted donapost turn up by the end of the week at the centre in Enderby, Leicestershire.But it was quickly taken down and was replaced with a notice attempting to reassure parents it had been posted in error by a member of staff at the firmaposs head office, reports Leicestershire Live.The biggest issue to emerge from the post referred to an incident last July when a child almost wandered out of the nursery and into the car park via a gate that had supposedly been left open by a staff member. It told how the staff member reported the incident to the then-manager and deputy manager. However the incident was not reported to the totaposs family, the head office or Ofsted, the company told the publication.  The company said the head office was only made aware of the incident in early January and that it had contacted the childaposs parents to inform them of what had happened. It added that an investigation into several incidents is currently underway with a new management team now running the nursery. Staff also acknowledged that workers did not whistle-blow to superiors after realising the management had not reported the incident however employees have since retrained to report such issues in future. The letter also detailed how a pre-school boy was trapped in the toilet for some time, leaving them visibly shaking and crying when let out. It claimed that the incident happened when a staff member was told to close the door to the bathroom to stop children running in and out and did not check the cubicles to seeany children were still left inside. Welcome Nurseries said the door was accidentally closed while the child was inside but staff then realised and ed to let him out. Other issues reported in the accidental post included a staff member wiping babiesapos bottoms with antibacterial wipes instead of wet wipes, causing the babies to have sore and bleeding bottoms. Meanwhile a cook was left to supervise pre-school children alone with no qualications to do so, it claimed. A child in soiled nappy was left unattended for so long that faeces was stuck to his leg and took  minutes to remove. One parent, whose child attends the nursery, said: The entire post is very worrying but my child attends the nursery section so I am particularly concerned that a member of staff was using antibacterial wipes on the babiesapos bottoms. I definitely havenapost been told about it and only found out due to the letter. We have to provide our own baby wipes so there was literally no excuse for them to use anything , they are completely dferent. They have covered staff mistakes up and we wouldnapost have known about itthe letter wasnapost posted. The nursery was already unreliable generally before this and had caused some concern, but hearing about a child escaping in the summer makes me worry , as a parent, will I find outmy child has been put at risk  Itaposs just a lot to hide. If theyaposd spoken with parents immediately at the time, there would have been some angry people, sure, but itaposs a lot better than keeping it a secret. The parent is looking to move their child to an alternative nursery in the near future. They added: The trust is gone with them. Iaposm having to move them to another nursery, which is a big disruption for a developing child, but itaposs something Iaposm having to do to ensure they are safe. Welcome Nurseries confirmed the management in charge of Smarties Nursery has changed since the incidents in question, and that the company was tackling the situation as a matter or urgency. The spokesperson said: We can confirm that we received an email of concern on the th January regarding alleged incidents that took place around July last year, under previous management. We can also confirm that we had no prior knowledge of the incidents until the email was sent to us. The safety and well-being of all our children are our number one priority and we immediately carried out a full investigation. It was alleged that a child managed to escape from the nursery into the car park. Whilst this allegation was unfounded, on investigation it was found that a gate was left open which was seen on CCTV by the receptionist, who acted immediately before the child went out of the gate. We also investigated further incidents which occurred around the same time in which a child was left in the bathroom on their own. Our investigation found that a child had entered the bathroom area and a member of staff not knowing he was there closed the door. Both incidents were reported to the previous management team who are no longer with the company, however these were not reported onward or investigated at the time. These incidents fall well below our standard of care and we have since retrained our staff. We are continuing to work with our parents and can assure all parents that we take all concerns seriously and act on them. We profusely apologise to all our children and parents that these incidents occurred and that we were not made aware of them sooner. We have not yet finished our investigations in this matter. We have a new management structure in place at the setting. We would also like to thank our parents for their continued support. A Leicestershire County Council spokesperson said: “We have very recently been made aware of concerns raised by a parent and will be working with the setting to ensure the appropriate procedures and policies are in place. news uk-news prince-andrew-loses-another-honour-"Prince Andrew stripped of military titles and royal patronagesByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan Prince Andrew has lost another honour after a school changed its name to distance itself from the Duke and his ongoing civil sex case. Head of Prince Andrew High School, Craig Campbell, in Nova Scotia sent an email to families explaining the name change - branding the decision exciting news. The email explained: The name of a school should be reflective of our school community and uphold our values as a safe and inclusive learning space for all. “Our hope is to continue to build our identity as a positive, supportive and respectful community, with a name to match.” The school was named in honour of the Queenaposs son in  after he was born. However, the name has been a point of concern since  - when Andrew was accused of having sex with an underage girl trafficked by paedophile friend Jeffrey Epstein.  Officials in the school originally formed committees in  to discuss a name change after the Duke of York was taken off royal duties as allegations against him began to circulate, despite his denials of any wrongdoing, reports New York Post. One mother of pupils at the school and chair of the school advisory council, Belinda Oxner, said in : As mother-of-three daughters, I find it very dficult to have that name on a building with the allegations and the associations now with the Prince Andrew name. The school will choose a new name in time ready for the new school year in September, the principal said. Mr Campbell added: We’re ready and excited to take this next step. It comes after the Queen stripped Andrew of his royal titles and patronages, meaning he will fight his accuser’s Manhattan lawsuit as a “private citizen.” A Buckingham Palace spokesperson said: With The Queen’s approval and agreement, The Duke of York’s military affiliations and Royal patronages have been ed to The Queen. The Duke of York will continue not to undertake any public duties and is defending this case as a private citizen. A royal source said: All of The Duke’s roles have been handed back to The Queen with immediate effect for redistribution to other Members of the Royal Family - will notto The Duke of York.  The Duke of York will no longer use the style ‘His Royal Highness’ in any official capacity. Prince Andrew served in the Royal Navy as a helicopter pilot and saw active service in the Falklands War. The royal said he stopped sweating after suffering an overdose of adrenaline while being shot at in the conflict.  The Duke revealed this medical condition in a BBC Newsnight interview when addressing Ms Giuffreaposs description of him sweating profusely. The royal has denied all allegations made against him, including claims he was sweating during a meeting with Ms Gufre. Prince Andrew has lost the following military affiliations:Honorary Air Commodore at RAF Lossiemouth Commodore-in-Chief of the Fleet Air Arm Colonel of the Grenadier Guards – Colonel Colonel in Chief of the Princess Louise Fusiliers of Canada Colonel in Chief of the Queenaposs York RangersColonel in Chief of the Royal Highland FusiliersColonel in Chief of the Royal Irish Regiment , rd and th and The Ulster Defence Regiment Colonel in Chief of the Royal New Zealand Army Logistic RegimentColonel in Chief of the Small Arms School Corps Colonel in Chief of the Royal LancersRoyal Colonel of the Royal Highland Fusiliers, nd Battalion The Royal Regiment of Scotland Colonel in Chief of the Yorkshire Regiment Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON The QueenPrince Andrew, Duke of YorkBuckingham PalaceRoyal NavyFalklands WarNewsnightEducationRoyal FamilySchoolsArmed forcesSecondary schoolThe Falklands" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news spoilt-prince-andrew-made-run-"Prince Andrew was known as Randy Andy says WitheridgeByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan Prince Andrew’s ex-maid has claimed he reduced her to tears with his bad temper and made her run up flights of stairs to shut his curtains. Charlotte Briggs, , said she agreed to take on the job that “nobody wanted” six months after starting work at Buckingham Palace in January, . She claimed he was aposdemanding and entitledapos while swearing at her when he wanted a task done and that he behaved like a aposspoiled brat.apos On leaving open a gap in the curtains he said: “Can’t you f***ing do anything right,” claimed Ms Briggs.The mum of two from Halax told The Sun that Andrew kept  teddy bears, many in sailor outfits and also had his ex-we Sarah Ferguson’s wedding dress. Due to offensive behaviour, she said she would even try to hide to avoid him, including behind the big heavy curtains. Her claims come after Andrew was stripped of his military affiliations and royal patronages by the Queen. He will no longer be able to use the title of His Royal Highness.The action was taken after a judge decided he would have to face a civil trial on sex abuse allegations made by Virginia Giuffre.The Duke of York vehemently denies the allegations. Ms Briggs told the outlet when she started working for him, Andrew was  and had just orced Fergie while also a veteran of the Falklands War.  She said: “This man fought for his country in the Falklands but couldn’t stand up to close his own curtains. It was utterly ridiculous but spoke volumes about him. Andrew definitely put a downer on things. He thinks he’s above everyone.” Ms Briggs told how she had moved from Yorkshire for the job and Andrew was based on the “nursery floor” where he and his siblings had grown up. She said that despite being an adult he wouldn’t do anything for himself. “There were two of us and we worked on a rota from .am to .am and then later on in the evening. We’d turn down his bed, remove his teddies, do the curtains and lay out his pyjamas. But he was a bad apple and behaved like a spoiled brat, she claimed. “Really you weren’t actually meant to be seen, you’d just sneak in and do stuff. But he was a bit lazy and he would call down from his office and say, ‘can you send the maid to shut the curtains’. They were literally behind him and massive — from floor to ceiling and as high as a house but he refused to get up and close them himself. She said that it was frustrating as she couldnapost say anything and being only -years-old she would cry about what was happening. Ms Briggs claimed he was worse than ladies-in-waiting who would get up and do some things for themselves. But she added the other royals like Charles and Edward were lovely. title: tinder charging young gay lesbian
story: Lesbian couple sitting in sofa, toasting wine" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _GettyImages-.jpg" width"" "" Some gay and lesbian users were paying moreImage: Getty ImagesByJosie ClarkeGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Dating app Tinder is charging young gay and lesbian users and people over  more for its premium service, an investigation claims to have discovered. Watchdog Which  says their exposé suggests possible discrimination and a breach of UK law.Which  asked almost  mystery shoppers to create real profiles and note the prices quoted by Tinder Plus, a premium package . The premium package features perks such as unlimited Likes and Rewinds and the ability to undo accidental selections. The research showed some gay and lesbian users were paying more, with an average premium of more than %compared to bisexual users, and more than %compared to heterosexual users.Do you use Tinder  Join the discussion in the comment section This trend was driven by the youngest age group, with Which  finding that gay and lesbian people aged  to  paid £. on average - % more than heterosexual users aged under and % more than bisexual users under  . When it came to age, those in the  to -year-old age bracket paid % more - a £ dference - and the over s paid % more - a £. dference - on average for a -month Tinder Plus subscription. Across the entire mystery shopping exercise, quotes for a yearaposs access to Tinder Plus ranged from £. to £., with  dferent prices quoted in total. The watchdog said Tinder did not make clear the full extent of how it applied personalised pricing on the app, with no explanation to customers that their personal data could be exploited in this way.  Which  said it had reported its findings to the Equality and Human Rights Commissionand the Information Commissioneraposs Officeand called on them to investigate whether there had been a breach of UK law. The Equality Act  makes it unlawful to charge people of one sexual orientation more than others unless there is a clear justication for this. Tinder said it was categorically untrue that our pricing structure discriminates in any way by sexual preference. It told Which  that older people did have to pay more in some countries, but said the price dference was a discount for younger users. Which  said this was not made clear to people using the app. The consumer group noted that it was occasionally justiable under UK law to offer age-based price iations for the same product or service, such as discounts to over-s or students, where it can be shown there is a legitimate basis for this. However, it said that in the case of Tinder it was unclear as to why over-s were paying more. Tinderaposs terms of use and privacy policy did not make users aware of such vastly dferent pricing, instead referring only to processing inidualsapos data to deliver and improve its services, to help keep users safe and to provide them with advertising that may be of interest. Tinder is owned by the Texas-based Match Group and made US . billion in global revenue in . Which  director of policy and advocacy, Rocio Concha, said: Our research uncovered concerning evidence that people using Tinder could unknowingly be facing higher charges because of their sexual orientation and age. This suggests possible unlawful price discrimination, whether or not it is intentional on Tinderaposs part, and potentially unlawful processing of personal data. We are calling for the EHRC and the ICO to investigate this issue further. If regulators decide that Tinderaposs personalised pricing is breaking the law, then the dating app giant must face strong action. A Tinder spokeswoman told Which : Tinder is free to use and the vast majority of our members enjoy our app without upgrading to the paid experience. However, we do offer a iety of subscription options to help our members stand out and match with new people more efficiently.  Tinder operates a global business and, in some geographies, we offer discounted subscriptions to younger members. In addition, we frequently offer promotional rates which can y based on factors like location orof subscription. No other demographic information is considered in our pricing structure. The spokeswoman added: It is categorically untrue that our pricing structure discriminates in any way by sexual preference. Any reporting or inference is patently  and outrageous. There are no truths to the Which  mystery shopping activity. An EHRC spokeswoman said: As Britainaposs equality regulator it is our job to protect, uphold and enforce equality laws. We take reports of discrimination very seriously. This report of potential discrimination by Tinder is concerning. We will consider these findings by Which  and respond in due course. title: woman 26 learns walk again
story: Woman, , learns to walk again after miraculously surviving ft waterfall plungeCara Sutton suffered a broken spine, shattered pelvis and collapsed lung after slipping on rocks near a waterfall edge. Her boyfriend thought she was dead, but she has now learned to walk againCara Sutton suffered injuries but is now back on her feet Image: Liverpool ECHOByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A woman who survived an ft waterfall plunge has beaten the odds for a second time by learning to walk again.Cara Sutton suffered a broken spine, shattered pelvis and collapsed lung in the drop. She had slipped on rocks metres from the waterfall edge then disappeared from view, leaving boyfriend James certain she was dead.The cycling helmet Cara was wearing probably saved her le at Coed-y-Brenin,Snowdonia, North Wales.The pharmacist, , who was on holiday, said: “I remember James shouting to be careful as I fell. “I was sliding all over the place and tried to grab some moss to stop myself but it just ripped off. “The edge was behind me so I didn’t realise I was about to fall until I saw the clf go past me.”  James said it was a miracle she had her helmet on, adding: “I thought there was no way she’d survive.” Rescuers winched her out of the ravine before flying her to Royal Stoke University Hospital. Cara, from Liverpool, had several operations and spent two months learning to walk again before being discharged in November. The emergency response will feature in Channel ’s : Critical Condition tonight.  Consultant Dr Richard Fawcett said such a plunge is usually deadly, adding: “There’s rocks and boulders... a height that can kill.” Cara said: “I can’t thank the doctors and rescue teams enough. “It feels amazing considering that just the other day I walked k. title: couple claim were turned down
story: Couple claim they were turned down by adoption agency because they are JewishGabriel and Elizabeth Rutan-Ram, of Tennessee, US, are suing the Christian-based adoption agency after they were denied foster parent training last yearElizabeth and Gabriel Rutan-Ram Image: FacebookByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A couple are suing the childrenaposs services department in Tennessee after an adoption agency refused to help them because they are Jewish.Gabriel and Elizabeth Rutan-Ram, of Knoxville, USA, said they were denied foster parent training and a home study certicate by Holston United Methodist Home for Children.They filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against the Christian -based agency, which is partly funded by the state, after trying to adopt a child last year. It is the first in Tennessee to challenge a new law that allows religious adoption agencies to deny service to families whose religious or moral beliefs do not match the provideraposs, their attorney told Knox News.Gabriel and Elizabeth realised they could not have biological children of their own last year and later found a child in Florida who they were excited to foster with plans to adopt, the publication added. They claim they were first told by Holston that the organisation would assist them with their out-of-state placement. But on the day they were due to begin training, they were told it only helped families who shared their Christian beliefs and the couple were unable to complete the fostering process, according to the lawsuit.  Elizabeth said: “I felt like I’d been punched in the gut. It was the first time I felt discriminated against because I am Jewish. It was very shocking and it was very hurtful that the agency seemed to think that a child would be better off in state custody than with a loving family like us.” The Rutan-Rams are currently fostering and hope to adopt a teenage girl through a separate agency with hopes of adopting again in the future, according to the US publication. Holston recently acknowledged receiving public money to offer foster care placement and training for the Tennessee Department of Child Services. It came when it sued the Biden administration last December over new federal regulations. The measures stopped government-funded health and human services programmes from discriminating due to religion, gender identity, sexual orientation, sex or same-sex marriage status. A spokesperson for the Tennessee Department of Child Services and the Tennessee Attorney Generalaposs offices declined to comment on the pending litigation. Alex Luchenitser, associate vice president and associate legal director at Americans United, issued a statement on behalf of the Rutan-Ram family. It read: The Tennessee Constitution, like the US Constitution, promises religious freedom and equality for everyone. Tennessee is reneging on that promise by allowing a taxpayer-funded agency to discriminate against Liz and Gabe Rutan-Ram because they are Jews. title: gabby petitos family florida speak
story: Gabby Petitos family in Florida to speak to FBI over unintentional mistakes in caseGabby Petitos family were in Florida today, four months after the -year-old disappeared while on a road trip around the US with boyfriend Brian LaundrieGabby Petito was murdered by partner Brian Laundrie while on a roadtrip around the US Image: gabspetito InstagramByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan | comments The family of murderedGabby Petito have met with the FBI for a briefing, according to reports.They were in Florida today four months after Gabby, , disappeared while on a road trip around the US with boyfriend Brian Laundrie. Laundrie strangled her to death before ing to his parentaposs home, subsequently taking his own le as a huge manhunt was launched for him.The families of Laundrie and Gabby have reached an agreement about how their joint property will be distributed, Fox News reports.Laundrieaposs parentsapos lawyer, Steven Bertolino, said he and the Petito family attorney, Rick Stafford, had been working together to come to an agreement on the distribution of property to be released from law enforcement.  A written agreement had been drawn up between them, he said. The belongings in question include a notebook found close to Laundrieaposs body, but Mr Bertolino declined to reveal which family would be keeping it. A probe into Gabbyaposs murder is still ongoing. Earlier this month an investigation found Utah police officers involved in the case made unintentional mistakes, recommending they were placed on probation.  The probe is looking at the police response into allegations of domestic violence against Laundrie. Laundrieaposs body was discovered at the Myakkahatchee Creek Environmental Park in Florida on October . The -year-old disappeared after ing from a cross-country road trip without his partner Gabby and was the lone suspect in her death. Her body had been found in a remote area in Wyoming on September , and a post-mortem confirmed she had been strangled.  A backpack and notepad belonging to Laundrie was found near his body and although the corpse had been scavenged by alligators and wild pigs, an examination of dental records proved conclusively that it was him. The Laundrie family’s attorney Steve Bertolino said in a statement to E! News: Chris and Roberta Laundrie have been informed that the cause of death was a gunshot wound to the head and the manner of death was suicide. Chris and Roberta are still mourning the loss of their son and are hopeful that these findings bring closure to both families. Gabby and Laundrie embarked on their trip in early July from New Yorkaposs Long Island, where her parents live. As they travelled through Kansas, Colorado, Utah and points west, Miss Petito documented their van le on social media.She posted her final photo to Instagram on August , the same day she last spoke to her mum by phone.They were seen quarrelling in August, with police in Utah releasing a video showing Miss Petito tearfully describing a dispute she had had with Laundrie. He was later named a person of interest in her disappearance, and on September  a federal grand jury in Wyoming indicted him on a charge of fraudulently using her bank debit card. title: man 21 said feels like
story: Man, , said he feels like hes wearing someone s face after horror crashMitch Hunter, , of Indiana, US, was left disfigured after the car he was travelling in ploughed into a pylon sending , volts of electricity through his bodyMitch Hunter was one of the first people in the world to have a full face transplant Image: tiktok @mitch.hunterByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan  A former soldier who was electrocuted in a horric car crash when he was just  became one of the first people in the world to have a full face transplant.Mitch Hunter, now , said it feels like he is wearing someone aposs face after the tragic accident which changed his le forever in . In a heroic act, Mitch pushed his female companion out of the way when the car they were travelling in crashed into a pylon sending , volts of electricity through his body. He absorbed the bulk of the blast and suffered unimaginable pain as the electricity travelled through his body and out his face. Itaposs someone aposs face, he told followers on TikTok after undergoing the face transplant surgery. Itaposs the donoraposs beard, hair follicles come with skin. Mitch, of Indiana, USA, lost his left leg, two fingers on his right hand and his face along with part of his memory shortly before and after the incident. Despite needing extensive skin grafts from his other leg and back, Mitch did not put himself forward for a face transplant until his we fell pregnant.Now a father-of-three, Mitch explained he initially went through with it because he did not want his children to be scared of his face, reports the Daily Star.A total of  doctors spent more than  hours reconstructing his face in an operation that saw his nose and lips replaced and his facial muscles and nerves reattached.  The brave survivor has shared his experiences on TikTok in his efforts to destigmatise face transplants. He added: Before the transplant, I would get stared at, comments made, and it just wasnapost fun, itaposs so much easier to live a normal le. Itaposs changed it considerably, itaposs a lot easier to go out in public and do normal things that normal people would do.
